Advantages of global navigation satellite system/flight management computer (GNSS/FMC) are in specific: 1. Capability for time and fuel revisions based on predicted and actual wind. 2. Disregarding limitations in uncontrolled airspaces during under IFR.

Limitations of using GNSS/FMC equipment include: 1. Errors by pilot-input, especially interchange of numbers when entering flight levels, wind, temperature, fuel. 2. The effect of other than predicted wind on fuel and time estimates.

Limitations of using GNSS/FMC equipment include: 1. Effect of aircraft's non-standard configuration on flight management system (FMS) predictions (e.g. in case of gear down). 2. Inability to store and display additional aeronautical information, like minimum altitudes, approach procedures.
Limitations of using GNSS/FMC equipment include: 1. Inaccuracy and loss of precision by FMS navigation calculations. 2. Aircraft mass significantly differs from that which was input by the crew.

Limitations of using GNSS/FMC equipment include: 1. Interchange of numbers when entering wind can result in a significantly different fuel burn up to the next waypoint from that predicted by the FMS. 2. Incorrect data entry will be detected resulting in rejection of input and a warning message.

question: A return to the departure point is required after flying 16 min at 100 kt TAS with a 20 kt tail wind. At a turn rate of 3º/s, the aircraft will arrive overhead the aerodrome after ...

options: Zero Fuel Mass, final reserve fuel, taxi fuel and contingency fuel
Zero Fuel Mass, final reserve fuel, alternate fuel and contingency fuel
Zero Fuel Mass, final reserve fuel and alternate fuel
Landing Mass at alternate, final reserve fuel, alternate fuel and trip fuel
